content: The "Preservation and Restoration of Orphan Works for Use in Scholarship and Education (PRO-USE) Act of 2005" and the "Preservation of Orphan Works Act" aim to address the reproduction of copyrighted works by libraries and archives. Additionally, the "National Film Preservation Act of 2005" focuses on the reauthorization and amendment of the National Film Preservation Act. The Librarian of Congress's duties under the National Film Preservation Act of 1996 are amended to include coordination of the national film preservation program with other collection, preservation, and accessibility activities. This involves expanding the scope to include copyrighted, mass distributed, broadcast, or published materials. The Librarian, under the National Film Preservation Act of 1996, is responsible for making films in the National Film Registry more accessible for research and educational purposes, updating the national film preservation plan to address technological advances, and preserving the moving image heritage of the United States. The National Film Preservation Act of 1996 is amended to support the preservation of various moving image formats and the work of the National Audio-Visual Conservation Center of the Library of Congress. The National Film Preservation Board's membership and reimbursement of expenses are also revised. The National Film Preservation Act of 1996 is amended to include responsibilities for the National Film Preservation Board, approval of special foundation projects, and utilization of the National Audio-Visual Conservation Center for storing preserved films in the National Film Registry. The National Film Preservation Act of 1996 is amended to ensure proper storage and dissemination of films in the National Film Registry in accordance with copyright laws. Amendments also include the use of the National Film Preservation Act seal in any format and changing the effective date from 7 to 19. Subtitle B--Reauthorization of the National Film Preservation Foundation. SEC. 221. REAUTHORIZATION AND AMENDMENT. Subtitle B of the National Film Preservation Foundation is being reauthorized and amended. The Board of Directors' composition and powers, as well as the authorization of appropriations, are being amended in various sections of title 36, United States Code. The National Film Preservation Foundation is amending the United States Code to authorize appropriations for the Library of Congress. The funds allocated are to match private contributions and cannot be used for administrative expenses. The National Film Preservation Foundation is amending the United States Code to authorize appropriations for cooperative film preservation initiatives approved by the corporation, the Librarian of Congress, and the National Film Preservation Board. The National Film Preservation Foundation is amending the United States Code to authorize appropriations for film preservation initiatives, including repatriation, exhibition, production of educational materials, and other activities to address unfunded preservation needs. Up to $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2015 for the Library of Congress to carry out these initiatives. The National Film Preservation Foundation is amending the United States Code to authorize appropriations for film preservation initiatives. Up to $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2015 to match private contributions made to the corporation. Amounts authorized under this section may not be used for administrative expenses. The National Film Preservation Foundation is amending the United States Code to authorize appropriations for film preservation initiatives by striking items relating to sections 151711 and 151712 and inserting new provisions. The National Film Preservation Foundation is amending the United States Code to authorize appropriations for film preservation initiatives, including cooperative film preservation and an annual report requirement.
